image.altText: Photo showing two small houses built on one block of land at Ainslie in Canberra.

items.synopsis: The zoning changes will allow dual-occupancies to be built on blocks that are 800 square metres or bigger, though onlookers expect few owners to take up the option.

title.children: More Canberrans will be allowed to split their block and build a second house

image.altText: DeanYates

items.synopsis: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of former foreign correspondent Dean Yates's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling.

title.children: 'I felt responsible': Dean felt guilty when his staff died. Then WikiLeaks released the footage

image.altText: A young boy looking at the camera while kneeling near a pile of rubble.

items.synopsis: Everyone left in Moulay Ibrahim has a story of their narrow escape — just ask 11-year-old Abdarazak Abou Aalam, whose tragic tour of the town starts at his neighbour's house, which was destroyed in Friday's earthquake.

title.children: In this devastated Moroccan village, an 11yo earthquake survivor gives a tour of the rubble

image.altText: Composite Kerry Frankcombe and marine rescue personnel.

items.synopsis: The six-metre half-cab has been found about 12 kilometres off Tasmania's north coast, but there is no sign of missing boatie Kerry Frankcombe.

title.children: Empty boat found at sea after Tasmanian man embarks on fishing trip

image.altText: Virtual reality technology being used to inform care for people with dementia

items.synopsis: A virtual reality tool called the Educational Dementia Immersive Experience — or EDIE — is helping aged care staff gain greater empathy and insight into what it's like for people living with dementia.

title.children: How gaming and virtual reality technology is being used to improve the care of people living with dementia

image.altText: Police tape strung between two witches hats blocking access to a gravel road

items.synopsis: Police divers will be deployed to Stockton Lake, near Collie, in a bid to find a man missing since Sunday.

title.children: Police search for man missing at popular WA swimming spot

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds a silver trophy

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic extends his dominance in men's tennis with a straight-sets victory over Daniil Medvedev to claim his 24th grand slam singles title and his fourth at the US Open.

title.children: 'What are you still doing here?': Dominant Djokovic wins record-equalling US Open title

image.altText: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis appear in a video apologising.

items.synopsis: Four of Danny Masterson's That '70s Show cast mates wrote character letters in support of the convicted rapist, including Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis.

title.children: Ashton Kutcher, Mila Kunis face growing backlash over Danny Masterson support

image.altText: an aerial view of an outback bushfire

items.synopsis: Authorities have been going door-to-door in parts of the town of Tennant Creek warning residents that a major bushfire could spread to the town amid extreme fire conditions.

title.children: Tennant Creek residents warned to prepare as major bushfire burns closer to outback town

image.altText: A man with a moustache and nose ring wearing a hat leans against a tree trunk.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: Ben was going to vote Yes to the Voice. Now he's a hard No

image.altText: Silhouette of Sydney CBD covered in smoke haze on September 11, 2023

items.synopsis: Smoke settles across many areas of Sydney as hazard reduction burning by the NSW Rural Fire Service continues ahead of a forecast warm and dry weekend.

title.children: Air quality 'very poor' in Sydney's east as firefighters 'catch up' on hazard reduction burning

image.altText: Oxfam office

items.synopsis: With unions embedding trials of the four-day work week in industrial agreements, is this the moment the working-hour-reducing concept goes mainstream?

title.children: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

image.altText: An illustration of a car, house, health kit and book in an opened gift box

items.synopsis: Some experts say a salary sacrifice or a salary package agreement can help maximise income and reduce tax debt — depending on the industry you're in and what your employer offers.

title.children: Ever heard of salary sacrifice? Here's what it is and how it can help reduce debt

image.altText: A man holds a bee with a tiny brown varroa mite attached to it.

items.synopsis: The deadly parasite moves further north in New South Wales, as a new more risk-based approach to controlling its spread is adopted, considering time of infestation, mite load and tracing on a case-by-case basis.

title.children: Hive euthanasia to be reassessed under new varroa mite response plan

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: Qantas' board remains under pressure ahead of its annual report, including over whether former CEO Alan Joyce should receive his full bonus, and what the board knew about the ACCC's ghost flights investigation. Meanwhile, the ASX is slightly higher. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board under pressure over Joyce bonus and ghost flights, tech stocks await iPhone 15 release, ASX up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Syrah Resources is on track to be the best performing stock today, and it's all thanks to the battery anode and graphite company being approved for a hefty loan. The company has been approved for a $150 million conditional loan by the United States International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) that will fund the capital requirements needed for its Balama Graphite Operations in Mozambique. The conditional loan commitment is subject to the completion of due diligence, negotiation of detailed terms and legal documentation, among other approvals. The DFC loan is for a maximum principal amount of $US150 million and a term of up to 13 years, with interest fixed at applicable long-dated US Treasury rates plus a margin. Syrah's managing director and CEO, Shaun Verner, said the loan approval demonstrates the importance of operation to the US and its critical minerals strategy. As a result of the loan, Syrah Resources has risen the most in 21 months, and is trading around $0.60.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's behind the buzz for Syrah Resources today?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a slow start to the week, the Australian sharemarket has picked up speed at lunch time, up 0.1% to 7,165 points at 1:20pm AEST. (If it's live figures you want to track, head to the top of the blog.) Looking at the sectors, financials are leading the gains, up 1.1%, followed by basic materials (+0.3%) and consumer non-cyclicals (+0.2%). Industrials are leading the losses, down 1.3%, while healthcare and real estate are down 0.9% each. As for the top movers, banks and financial groups are leading the charge: Syrah Resources +5.7% Magellan Financial Group +4.3% Bank of Queensland +3.2% Bendigo and Adelaide Bank +2.8% Link Administration +2.3% As for the bottom movers, weak commodity prices are dragging mining stocks down: Sims -11.1% Megaport -9% Lake Resources -6.6% Bellevue Gold -5.9% Chorus -4.2%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX picks up speed at lunch, led by gains in banks as mining stocks slip

children.content: After a slow start to the week, the Australian sharemarket has picked up speed at lunch time, up
(If it's live figures you want to track, head to the top of the blog.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ahead of a law change later this year, the ACCC is urging businesses to review their standard contracts and amend or remove unfair contract terms before new penalties come into force. From November 9, businesses will be prohibited from proposing, using, or relying on unfair contract terms in standard form contracts with consumers and small businesses, under changes to the Australian Consumer Law. The changes mean businesses and individuals could face "substantial" penalties by the courts, instead of just having courts declare specific terms of a contract unfair and void. The ACCC's deputy chair Mick Keogh says the changes should motivate businesses to correct their contracts before the new penalties are enforced. "There was previously little motivation for businesses to comply with the law, despite the ACCC's compliance and enforcement actions. We s trongly urge businesses to review their contracts now to ensure they comply ," he said. "The test for whether a contract term is unfair has not changed. However, businesses now could potentially face substantial penalties for contravening the law. This will better protect consumers and small businesses who have limited bargaining power, expertise, and ability to negotiate or assess standard form contracts. "While some of the changes won't apply to contracts until they are renewed, or a new contract is entered into, businesses should be proactive in reviewing their standard form contracts now ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACCC urges business to review unfair contract terms before law change later this year

image.altText: A dark-haired man in his 30s and his mother, about 60, sit in front of a tent with their two dogs.

items.synopsis: Matt Turner has a job and perfect tenancy references, but the housing crisis has left him at his lowest point.

title.children: There are 40 vacant houses nearby, so why is this employed 34yo living in a tent with his mum?

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police continue to search for two men after a fatal shooting at a Keilor cafe, as CBD traders raise fears about Melbourne's reputation.

title.children: Search continues for two offenders after fatal cafe shooting of underworld figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: newspaper clippings surrounding old photographs of a man

items.synopsis: Premier Daniel Andrews's new inquiry has been tasked with untangling a web of horrors relating to just 18 Victorian government schools. The single case of serial paedophile headmaster William Landman shows why a broader examination is needed, writes investigative reporter Russell Jackson.

title.children: Prolific paedophile William Landman was a criminal before he was a teacher. He and other abusers will not be examined in a new inquiry

image.altText: A dingo looks out from atop a hill

items.synopsis: Rangers are pleading with visitors to K'gari to heed warnings about dingoes ahead of school holidays as another one is destroyed due to its dangerous interactions with humans.

title.children: Rangers euthanase dingo involved in high-risk attacks, the third to be destroyed this year

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Spanish Football Federation chief Luis Rubiales, engulfed in a scandal over giving an unsolicited kiss to a player on the women's World Cup team last month, says he will resign from his position.

title.children: Spain's soccer chief Luis Rubiales announces resignation over unsolicited kiss

image.altText: Origins of tuberculosis

items.synopsis: Authorities in one of Australia's most remote communities say the state government "hasn't stepped in to do anything" to support screening efforts locally, after a woman who spent time there died from tuberculosis.

title.children: Remote WA community still waiting for urgent tuberculosis testing nine months after 19yo's death

image.altText: Tash smiling in a selfie, wearing an off-the-shoulder long sleeve pink dress with floral print.

items.synopsis: Growing up I always assumed I'd have kids. But at 15 I discovered I had a rare syndrome that meant I could never carry my own.

title.children: I expected to have a couple of kids, but I've made peace with being childless

image.altText: A little boy in a fluffy hoodie plays with his mother in a living room.

items.synopsis: Max Knight's mother begged him not to leave her as he lay dying in her arms after a fire on their Queensland property. His dad was badly injured in the blaze and remains in hospital.

title.children: Community rallies after 5yo dies in mum's arms following Father's Day fire

image.altText: A blue ANZ Bank sign is seen at a bank branch in Martin Place, Sydney.

items.synopsis: When Victor Shaw discovered that scammers had stolen his dad's life savings, he held out little hope of a positive outcome. But then a letter arrived from ANZ that left him stunned.

title.children: 'Absolutely astonished': Victor's dad lost his life savings to scammers, but the bank paid it all back

image.altText: A brown snake with its tongue out on a rock

items.synopsis: Experts say how you respond in the minutes after a snake bite could be the difference between life and death. It comes after the tragic death of a man bitten by a suspected brown snake while trying to save a friend in North Queensland.

title.children: Snake season has turned deadly. Here's what to do if you get bitten

image.altText: AFL players playing a game

items.synopsis: Two men have been charged with assaulting police officers after spectators stormed the field at a country footy final in Queensland.

title.children: Police officers allegedly assaulted after 'disgusting' incident at outback Australian Rules grand final

image.altText: A man and woman hugging in front of a for sale sign at a house

items.synopsis: China made it much harder for money to leave the country in 2017. Our study looked at Sydney home prices before and after that crackdown — and these are the suburbs where we found they changed, writes Song Shi.

title.children: How much did Chinese investors drive up Sydney home prices?

image.altText: Anthony Albanese stands behind a podium that says G20.

items.synopsis: As the hosts of the G20 tried to steer discussions towards other issues, the Ukraine war still dominated, reinforcing the deep global divisions.

title.children: Ukraine, climate change and India's name change: These were the key takeaways from the G20 summit

image.altText: Rainbow light in the form of soundwaves on a black background.

items.synopsis: There's a colour of noise for every mood. But are these sounds really useful for getting to sleep, or concentrating better? That depends on you.

title.children: White noise might help you learn a new language, but be wary of other claims around coloured noise

image.altText: Joe Biden stands behind a lectern with a Vietnamese flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Vietnam elevates the US to the strategic South-East Asian nation's highest diplomatic status after US President Joe Biden arrives in Hanoi to an honour guard and school children waving American flags.

title.children: US-Vietnam ties elevated to highest level since Vietnam War, amid tensions with Beijing

image.altText: Man in red jacket with light on his head

items.synopsis: More than 150 rescuers are racing to save an American researcher who became trapped in a cave in southern Türkiye, moving him halfway to the surface.

title.children: Caver trapped 1,000 metres deep in Türkiye is moved halfway to surface

image.altText: Listen Out Festival in Sydney, 2018

items.synopsis: Your place for today's latest news, as it happened.

title.children: Calls for pill testing in NSW ahead of summer music festival season. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera holding up a big tray of animal treats.

items.synopsis: With her all-woman workforce and biscuits that look good enough for humans to eat, Emma Gibbons is breaking into a multi-billion-dollar global market of animal lovers splurging on spoiling their pets.

title.children: Iced doggie doughnuts and pony treats catapult Emma into a multi-billion-dollar market
